reviewText:
I don't think I've ever played a game more irreverent and wacky in its humor and design while also keeping to one of the most accurate and precise physics engines I've seen in a while.

Worms Reloaded is actually an updated rerelease of Worms 2: Armageddon (Do not confuse this with Worms: Armageddon. They're actually two totally different games) released in 2009 and while it's one of the older titles in the Worms franchise, it is definintely the one with the most features, gameplay modes, options, and overall fun out of the games I've played.

Up to four teams each control a squad of four worms with customizable names, voices, and hats (in fact the Steam version has TF2-themed hats just for this occasion) and an arsenal of weapons ranging from rocket launchers, grenades, flamethrowers, and air strikes to ninja ropes, teleporters, and magnets to a variety of exploding wildlife and grandmas to the mighty meteorific field-wide death of Armageddon.  These worms will use said weapons to blow the living hell out of each other in a manner befitting old-school Looney Toons designed by Michael Bay.  Each worm only has a finite amount of time to make a move, inch across the battlefield, use whatever weapon or item they wish and end their turn.  A surprsing amount of things can get done during this time, but moves must be planned very carefully as just about any situation can be used against you somehow if your opponent is creative enough.

The controls on the weapons are all fairly simplistic but at the same time surprisingly complicated.  The physics engine is very in depth taking into account, angle, power put behind the shot or throw, wind power and direction, and the presence of any obstacles.  The precision in which things can be done is fairly impressive and a competent player can do things that might not even seem possible.  It is worthy to note while keyboard controls are present, a controller is generally recommended for this game due to how strange buttons are mapped originally, but this can be changed.  Gravity effects everything BUT the terrain you're standing on.  The randomly generated maps and backgrounds will stay put no matter how many pieces are blown apart until you're either sitting in a crater, traverssing tunnels, or recreating Bastion.  However, even a remaining pixel can be the difference between a hit or a miss in some cases so keeping track of what was destroyed how can sometimes work to your advantage but freak accidents can always happen.

One thing that's consistent throughout any worms game, especially in multiplayer, is that no matter how good one side is compared to the other, random chain reactions and other assorted problems can show up as a result of anything happening.  A grenade could be thrown and throw an enemy worm into a mine, which detonates a nearby gas canister that lights an area on fire that eats through the ground and frees up a hole for someone else to fall into- right onto a health crate that fell down previously.  But by no means is this a luck-based game.  Freak happenings aside, the mechanics, complex physics, and sheer creativity allowed in the vast arsenal of weapons and tools requires quick reflexes, careful planning, and a good knowledge of how the game works and mastering these can take quite a bit of practice.

While this game is best played with friends, the single-player campaign is long and full of missions ranging from puzzles to challenges, to simply difficult missions and the AI at later levels is surprsingly advanced given how complex the rest of the game is.  Unfortunately, the campaign isn't really worth playing more than once as each mission has a special 'trick' to it that can render it fairly easy in the hands of a skilled player.  The actual multiplayer is where most of the action is.  Randomly generated landscapes of a variety of colors, themes and backgrounds from ancient Egypt to Hell to outer space never makes for the same game twice and customizable maps and game modes allow for more exacting factors to be controlled ahead of time should you wish it.  Due to the antics of how the game works, I recommend you play with actual friends either in person (It's worth noting that local multiplayer only needs a single controller) or online, but online multiplayer is also a perfectly viable option.  Fair warning to those who care, however: There is no word censor in this game and enemy team or word names you come across online can be inappropriate.

Overall this is a fantastic multiplayer game that, if plugged into a large monitor, projector, or TV can make a fantastic couch party game that doesn't rely heavily on the RNG, but has just enough chance to allow laughs at a chain of explosions due to a misplaced land mine.  There's enough customization to keep games from getting boring or samey and custom teams are always fun to deal with and it's very easy to personify the little guys and give each of your team a distinct personality or strategy type in your head.  The single-player allows for a lot of time invested and makes for good practice and a rewarding experience by itself.  Still, only get this game if you plan on playing it with friends.

reviewText:
Get ready folks, 2D Worms and back in action!
Team 17 presents: The Return of Worms in Worms ReloadedEver since the time the team switched from 2D to 3D, the Worms games had become mediocre. However, the developers have heard the fans voices - reverting back to the old school 2D classic we all know to love! After winning the game in a giveaway, I decided I'd review it right here for you guys!

What is Worms ReloadedWorms is a 2D platform game which can be played alone or with friends online.The main attraction to the game is that you can blow your enemies to smithereens, destroying them in any way you want to, whether that be prod of kamikazes!

If you wish to know more about the specifics of this game, check them out on steam. As well as this, you can check out the official website here for more information on the entire Worms games series!

CampaignIn the campaign mode, you'll compete in up to 35 single player missions, as well as having warzone missions to keep you entertained once those have been completed. As well as this, for those who have never played the game, there is quite an informative tutorial, giving you all the intel required to play and master Worms.

As well as this, you also have other game modes to experience. You could try your luck with the bodycount mode, which is basically a survival - beware, only the experienced player will beat this, you'll have to be amazing at the game to survive!

As for the campaign, it's not really all too difficult. Planning beforehand and strategizing your movements will allow you to easily defeat the campaign. Along with the side-missions, the single player will probably give you around 10 to 15 hours of solid, fun gameplay.

GameplayThe gameplay is the same formula all the other games of the series has used, the movement is done via a simple input with the arrow keys, and jumping with the enter key. Shooting and aiming is done with the space bar and arrow keys (up and down), with different weapons being selected with your mouse.

The game is amazingly fun, the unpredictability of the enemy team and the amount of customizability with weapons and other factors make it amazingly fun, giving you the nostalgic feeling of being back in the early 00's playing the old-school Worms game we all know and love.

The acrobatic techniques such as backflips and other amazing stunts help you scale platforms otherwise not possible with a normal jump. With many platforms and different maps to consider (though they'll all destructible), the Worms game offers a unique experience like no other!

Note; As for the controls, the game can also be played with a gamepad as well. It's absolutely great, works like a charm and is a lot less clumsy than the keyboard and mouse configuration.

After playing the game extensively, I'll rate the gameplay 9/10. It's fun, very well polished and comes across as a great aspect of the game.

MultiplayerThe multiplayer is really what makes the game what it is. Without it, it'd be a lot less fun and let's be honest, who wants to fire against the AI all day? New features to this great addition to the series include voice chat and the ability to invite steam friends when making a private match.

Multiplayer provides two options when hosting matches, private or public games. Once your friend/enemy appears in your lobby, you can start warming up for the battle. There are some options above your name which details the value of worms you have and what color your team will be.

Before starting the game, the host is able to choose what level you are going to battle in. As well as the levels included in the game, user-created levels can be used, which is quite challenging and amazingly fun, especially if you have not played the map before.

The option for online chat is always there, in every game. Screaming down the microphone is always fun, and with the press of a button you can chat to all your fellow worms within any online game that you play on the servers. It's best to play with friends, but it's also great to take your aggression out on those strangers from around the world!

Upon playing this game a lot via online and with a few friends, I'd rate the multiplayer portion of the game around 8/10. There are some flaws and the voice chat definitely needs some work, but other than that it's filled with epic, fun maps that will keep you entertained for many hours.

Note: You can play with 2~4 players at once in a multiplayer match, as well as playing LAN if you have some friends over.

GraphicsGraphics are amazing to see, there are a lot of new HD effects, all of which enhance the bomb explosions, jetpack animations etc. The developers have also added a nice little feature in the game, the worms scream when in danger.

There are also upgrades on the visual and aesthetic measures of the game, including new voices, new gravestones, as well as the addition of odd, funny hats for the worms, which is a welcomed addition to the game too.

Because of the vast improvements from the game's predecessors, I'll be rating this game a 9/10 for graphics. It's been vastly improved, giving the Worms games a whole new look and feel to it. Absolutely stunning visuals, especially for a game within this genre!

Extra & SpecialsFor everyone who took a pre-order of this, you'll receive exclusive in-game items, as well as the DLC. If you play or have Team Fortess 2, you'll have been rewarded with some special items for that, too.

As well as this, Worms Reloaded has a in-game shop, where you can buy hats, landscapes, missions, weapons, gravestones and forts for your Worms.

Since the Summer of 2011 there has been alot of DLC releases.

ConclusionThis game is worth buying, it brings back the old 2D Worms with a bang and a sense of nostalgia, which is always a good thing. Achievements have made a comeback too, which is always great to see in a game like this.

I'd recommend this to all my friends over here! So hurry up and grab this game today! It's time to blast some worms out of the park!

reviewText:
A right step forward, a good step backwards
Back when I was browsing a certain Scandinavian video game online store I came across a game called Worms Reloaded. At first I couldn't believe my eyes. How could've I missed this game? I decided to take a look what kind of game it was. Seeing only a single screenshot I knew I had to get this game. It reminded me of the simpler times. It reminded me about my old Pentium 2 PC that just barely ran Worms Armageddon.

Worms Reloaded is a 2D-strategy game developed by Team 17. The game features a team based action-strategy experience where you have to eliminate the enemy team with wacky and fun wepaons. Those of you who are not familiar what makes Worms game differ from other strategic games is the way weapons, items and environment change the phase of the gameplay. You can use your weapons for dealing damage or blasting your way through dirt. Weapons can be used to modify your surrondings and tools can be used as deadly weapons. The way you use the gadgets you are given is the key to fun and challenging gameplay.

The game features different kind of game modes ranging from basic campaing missions to elimination game mode towards more challenging game modes like time trials and puzzles. There's a lot of thing to do and is definetly worth playing even as a single-player experience.

Even though Worms Reloaded could be argued to be a modern Worms game it still feels right and controls like a classic 2D-Worms game. It even pays homage to older Worms games by including some older maps in the game. And that makes Worms Reloaded worth buying. It is well made. It is fresh. It is amazing.

Lastly, as a bit of a personal suggestion, I would suggest for you to get the DLCs. I usually never get them but seeing how many hours they add to the game (easily 50 hours) it is more than advised for you to get them if you enjoyed the base game.

reviewText:
If you've never played a Worms game before, WHAT THE CRAP, MAN?!  STOP READING THIS AND BUY IT NOW!!

If you have played a Worms game before, this is one is still a blast.  I played Worms Armegeddon when it came out, installed it on my high school's network harddrive so that every student who logged on could access it and play wonderfully silly local games.  And, boy, did we.  All the time.  And you could hear cursing and laughter throughout the computer lab (followed by everyone alt-tabbing or turning off the computer monitor when a teacher came over to question what we were doing).

Almost fifteen years later, Reloaded has been brought back all that hilarious joy that's definitely on par with Armageddon.  Local and online multiplayer is wonderful.  Lots of cursing and laughter with friends (we don't have to hide it from any teachers this time).  And really this is why you buy this game.  Hilarious, goofy weapons to blow up your friends and curse/laugh when you fail miserably and accidentally blast yourself to smithereens.


What?  You're still reading?  All right, I can say more.
Good things:
-Steam Achievements: a ton of achievements that make you work (some are ridiculously hard).
-Multiple platforms:  I play on Mac and Windows both.  It's nice to have an option.
IMPORTANT NOTE: You cannot play across platforms online (I have to play on my Windows laptop when playing with friends since most of them don't have a Mac).
-Map Editor is fun.

Some Blah things:
-The single player campaign is nice but it felt a bit short.  For a really great extended Solo experience, you'll want to buy the DLC or the Game of the Year Edition.  (GOTY includes all DLC and provides some excellent challenges.)
-A LOT of Steam Achievements are linked to the DLC, so you'll have to purchase them separately or the GOTY Edition to get all of them.  BUT DLC only works for Windows.  So even when buying GOTY Edition, you can only play the base game on Mac and Linux.

The game is worth the money at full price, but it goes on sale pretty often, so I recommend keeping an eye open to snag the game for $5 or better.  (~$6.50 for GOTY)

reviewText: Mostly the same as Worms: Armageddon or Worms World Party, but with graphical improvements and minor details such as hats for the Worms, which helps to visually distinguish different teams.  Limiting team rosters to 4 worms (instead of the previous 8) is probably the biggest change, and certainly the biggest negative one.  A few weapons have been phased out (mine strike, for example) and a few new ones have been introduced (such as poison strike and the healing lightning strike).  The solo missions are less maddening, on average, than in previous games in the series, making it a better experience for new players.  It has also streamlined different game modes and incorporated new styles, such as time attack races and vertical maps, ideas which were originally incorporated by community hacks to W:A.\n\nOverall, it's still a tremendously fun game.  The one real disappointment is that even with the Retro Pack, not all of the maps from previous editions of Worms are available for play.  However, importing one's own custom maps in image format is quite easy.

reviewText:
Some people may argue that Worms Armageddon is superior in some ways. And, after actually learning Armageddon's controls and spending a lot of time with it, I have to agree.

I used to think this one was a lot more solid, too, and was the definitive Worms game in my eyes. But after playing a lot of Armageddon, once again, that has changed.

However, no one can argue that this one is a LOT more intuitive. You can use a gamepad if you want, and the keys are remappable for whatever method you're using. You aren't stuck having to look up the complicated and confusing controls of Armageddon on the internet (Though, they work pretty well once you know them. And they were actually quite easy to learn).

The fact is that if you want to get into Worms, or get your friends into worms, this is the best way to do it, bar none.

Also, Worms Reloaded is the best version of Worms 2: Armageddon. Don't settle for the less refined console releases. This game will run on whatever computer you have; you have no excuse.

(Another thing to note, is that this game does have some features that Armageddon doesn't, though that works both ways; Armageddon has a lot of things Reloaded doesn't have either. If you enjoy this one, try Armageddon. And, you know.....vice-versa)

reviewText:
The Worms series has long been held dear by its fans for its endearingly comical, cartoony and unconventionally turn-taken nature of battle, and in my personal regard, offers a gaming experience that I highly value and recommend as an ideal respite from the typically hectic shoot 'em up fare. Whenever I want to relax, have fun and enjoy a good few laughs dispatching foes without the pressure of real time vigilance demanded by first person shooters, Worms is most definitely where it's at.

If you're new to Worms, Reloaded is perhaps the best iteration through which to get acquainted with this loveable series. It's visually crisp and vibrant whilst being effortless to run for the majority of systems, with gameplay that is unwaveringly slick and reponsive; a refined culmination of all the earlier iterations that adhere to the classic 2-D visual format.

There's one prevalent trait of Worms games that makes them somewhat notorious - it's ever so easy to make a blunder, whether it's by virtue of throwing a grenade only to have it fall in the vicinity of an ally or even bounce right back at you; underestimating the amount of jetpack fuel required to reach your desired destination and then dropping like an ill-fated little stone; fumbling an ambitious attempt to ninja rope across a body of water and plopping straight into it - the list of both witnessed and hypothetical follies goes on, and this is a notable part of what makes Worms so pricelessly tide-turning and amusing although unsuitable for those excessively proud individuals who could never so much as poke fun at themselves!

reviewText:
Introduction:
Ten years on from Worms Armageddon and the turn-based comic mayhem continues in Worms Reloaded, an all-new edition available for PC through Steam. Worms Reloaded features up to four player online and offline multi-player, voice support, a raft of crazy new weapons and the return of some iconic weapons from the brandâ€™s celebrated past.
We all know and love Worms, Worms Reloaded brings all we love and gives it a new lick of paint. Its all here from holy hand grenades to exploding sheep and even the odd poke for good measure.


Story:
There is no story per-say to worms, but it does feature a campaign mode thatâ€™s pretty comprehensive. Worms is simply about worms at war, thereâ€™s no rhyme or reason to it. But you will come to love your own group of worms. Worms has always oozed character and Reloaded is no different.

Gameplay:
If you have ever played Worms then nothing has changed, but if its not broken why fix it. Worms plays beautifully, even someone who hasnâ€™t played before will soon be comfortable with the controls. In fact I put this to the test when reviewing it, we had a gaming night and after a few minutes my 8 year old had mastered the controls. For me thatâ€™s where Worms really shines, Its good to play on your own but even better with friends. There are very few games that span generations, but Worms achieves this as its loved by young and old alike.

Presentation:
The graphics looked great ten years ago and nothing has really changed, its still those loveable little guys brandishing heavy artillery. It wont push your system even without a discreet graphics card, but its all well drawn and looks great.
Worms isnâ€™t about amazing graphics, its about fun. The presentation is great and you really will love these little guys but Crysis its not, nor does it want to be. The animation is smooth and its visually appealing.

reviewText: Out of the last few Worms games released, this one is still pretty good. It's a bit cut down from Armageddon but still runs nicely on lower-end systems, more than can be said for Revolution and onwards. There's no real reason to get any of the DLC except maybe Forts if you're really into that mode, just grab the base game on sale sometime.

Most of what needs to be said about this game alone has already been said, I'm just going to outline the differences between this and Worms: Armageddon.

Pros:Steam integration, easy to set up a multiplayer game and play with friends. Also Steam Cloud saves!
Nice graphics that are definitely a step up from Armageddon's ageing '98 256-colour look. Now with cute dancing animations!
UI is a bit clunky but much MUCH better than Armageddon's.
Enhanced level generator capable of generating more types of levels.
Many of the weapons have been streamlined and are easier to use.
New customisation options for pimping your teams.
New speech banks, while keeping some of the classic Armageddon banks. (it only gets feta!)
Integrated speech bank editor.
Cons:Only matchmaking, no WormNET/Servers. Online community is dead, go get Armageddon if this is what you want.
No LAN support...
Generally less weapons/items than Armageddon. (some of them I don't miss)
Doesn't seem to be a way to make maps out of images.
No cross-platform multiplayer (can't play a game with a copy for a different OS), which doesn't affect me since all my friends use Windows.
AI is even worse now. It either does something really stupid or it pulls off a shot with perfect accuracy, even on the lowest difficulty (tends to do more of the latter on higher difficulties).
Custom speech banks are not synced by Steam Cloud.
Not as much modding support as Armageddon.
No Whoopsie speech bank :C (I'll come back y'know!)
Some of the content is locked behind DLC, which isn't the case with Armageddon.
Overall, I recommend this game to newcomers to the series and people who just want to play with their friends. People who would rather join the Worms community will be better off purchasing Armageddon instead, so long as they can put up with its age.

Other than that, it's pretty fun, and it could still be fantastic, if the devs ever decide to get off their asses and patch it into a real PC version. But controls can make or break a game, and in this case, they broke it hard.

Worms Reloaded is everything we know and love about the worm series, from the original worms on the PC, to worms on the GBC/GBA, to the worms world party and of course worms 3d on the gamecube.

The Worms are back in yet another game, but fear not - there's little attempt for risky innovation here, no this is a simple amalgamation of ideas that Team 17 proved worked 10 years ago.\n\nYes, Worms Reloaded can be considered to just be Worms Armageddon +, and in many ways this is right. The premise is exactly the same, the weapons are exactly the same (save for a few new ones), the physics, humour, & the modes which people will be spending 90% of their time are exactly the same. However, this is really refinement at it's best. The new bells and whistles make this incarnation of Worms into a 2010 and beyond experience. Seamless Steamworks support, achievements, HD sheen and interface, DLC, and tons of customizability mixed with the proven gameplay is the perfect molotov cocktail to keep you still coming back for more.
